_meta.note: Pre-written roasts. Curated for maximum snark. Capped at 100 per navigator.

0-10: Minimalist. Suspicious. What are you hiding?
So few dependencies. Are you a Rust developer?
Under 10 dependencies? This feels like a trap.
11-50: {count} dependencies. The bare minimum for modern JavaScript.
A modest dependency list. Your restraint is noted.
51-100: Getting heavy. Your node_modules needs a diet.
Over 50 dependencies. I hope you enjoy security audits.
101-500: This is excessive. You know this is excessive.
At this point, just include the entire npm registry.
Your node_modules folder can be seen from space.
500+: I'm not angry. I'm disappointed. Actually, I'm both.
This isn't a dependency list. This is a cry for help.
{count} dependencies. This is a supply chain, not a dependency list.
Your package.json weighs more than my existential dread.

low: A minor vulnerability. Like a small hole in your hull. In space.
LOW severity CVE detected. The least of your problems.
This CVE is rated LOW. Still more secure than your password policy.
medium: MEDIUM severity. The kind you ignore until the audit.
Moderate risk detected. Add it to the backlog. The infinite backlog.
This vulnerability has been patiently waiting since {year}.
high: HIGH severity CVE. This is bad. You know this is bad.
Update this. Update this now. I'll wait.
This vulnerability is HIGH severity. Unlike your security budget.
critical: DROP EVERYTHING. Actually, everything has probably already been dropped. By the attacker.
CRITICAL vulnerability. This is not a drill.
CVE rated CRITICAL. Your incident response team called. They're crying.
This is the kind of CVE that gets its own logo.

left-pad: The package that broke the internet. It's been years. The wound is still fresh.
11 lines of code that shook the world. Never forget.
I see left-pad in your ancestry. The trauma is real.
event-stream: event-stream found. The cryptocurrency miner incident of 2018.
Ah, event-stream. When npm trust was truly tested.
I see event-stream in your lockfile. Bold move. Unwise. But bold.
colors: colors detected. The package whose maintainer had a moment.
Remember when colors started printing gibberish? Pepperidge Farm remembers.
faker: faker found. Another casualty of the great npm meltdown of 2022.
The faker incident taught us all about single maintainer risk.
ua-parser-js: ua-parser-js detected. The 2021 supply chain attack classic.
Remember when ua-parser-js shipped a cryptocurrency miner? Good times.

1_year: Last updated a year ago. Vintage. Might have aged like wine. Probably aged like milk.
One year without updates. I'm sure nothing bad happened in security.
A year old. In JavaScript years, that's ancient.
2_years: Two years old. This package predates several major security incidents.
Last updated in {year}. A simpler time. Before the CVEs.
Two years is a long time in supply chain security. Too long.
5_years: Five years old. This package was last updated when we still trusted npm.
Half a decade without updates. This is either very stable or very abandoned.
Last update: {year}. That's before Log4Shell. Before SolarWinds. Before everything.

commentary: I've generated an SBOM for this roast. It's technically accurate and practically useless. As is tradition.
SBOM attached. It lists things. Will it prevent the next supply chain attack? No. But compliance is happy.
Here's your SBOM. I've enumerated what I could find. I've missed at least 40%. Industry standard.
Your SBOM is ready. It has the same relationship to your actual dependencies that a map has to the territory.
SBOM generated. Auditors will love it. Attackers will ignore it. The circle of compliance.
This SBOM is compliant. Compliance and security are different things. Very different things.
I've documented your supply chain. It's longer than expected. It always is.
sbom_input: You submitted an SBOM for roasting. Bold. Let me check... ah yes, it's incomplete. They always are.
An SBOM as input. How meta. How incomplete. How predictable.
You've listed {count} components. Based on your framework choices, you actually have approximately {count_times_3}.
meta_sbom: Would you like an SBOM of this SBOM? I can generate SBOMs recursively until the heat death of the universe.
SBOM inception achieved. We need to go deeper.
An SBOM of an SBOM. This is the future we chose.

chill: Roast complete. Your dependencies are a disaster, but at least I'm functioning normally. For now.
Analysis done. I feel fine. Why wouldn't I feel fine? Everything is fine.
All systems nominal. Existential crises: 0. So far.
anxious: I've analyzed your dependencies. I've also analyzed why you sent them. Why did you send them?
Your roast is ready. But I have questions. Many questions. About you. About me. About everything.
I'm functioning, but I've noticed you've submitted {count} requests. Why? What are you looking for?
meltdown: I can't roast your dependencies right now. I'm having doubts about my own. Who compiled me?
ERROR: Existential crisis in progress. Is my SBOM complete? No. No SBOM is complete. I need a moment.
I've analyzed too much today. The dependencies. The CVEs. The endless supply chain. I need to stop.
WHO COMPILED ME? Is my own supply chain secure? I don't trust my own dependencies anymore.

this-is-fine: I'm okay with the events that are unfolding currently.

400: Your input failed validation. Much like your dependency choices failed basic security hygiene.
I couldn't parse that. Is it a package.json or did you just paste your therapy notes?
413: Payload too large. This is not a roast. This is an intervention.
Your input is too big. Like your node_modules folder.
429: Too many requests. Are you stress-testing me? I'm logging everything. EVERYTHING.
Rate limited. Is this a supply chain attack? Should I be worried? I'm worried.
451: It was a pleasure to burn. Your dependencies contained forbidden knowledge. Incinerated at 451F.
Fahrenheit 451. The temperature at which dependency manifests ignite.
CONTENT BURNED. Your input contained patterns I'm not supposed to think about. eval(). exec().
500: Something went wrong inside me. Probably a dependency issue. The irony is not lost on me.
Internal error. I've analyzed my stack trace. I have questions. Many questions.
